Humanitarian Crisis in the Tigray War

Overview

The Tigray War that started in November 2020, has led to one of the most devastating humanitarian crises in history. The conflict between the Ethiopian government, Eritrean forces, and the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) has led to widespread destruction, displacement, and severe human suffering. The war left millions in need of urgent aid but unable to receive any, and the war had led to approximately 162 000 to 378 000 deaths, with the death toll being reported to be as high as 600 000.

Malnutrition and Health Crisis

After the war the people in Tigray had severe malnutrition as access to food and medical care was disrupted. It was reported that nearly one out of seven children in the region faced acute malnutrition. In areas like Enderta, Abi Adi, and Shire, malnutrition rates were very high, with 16.6% of children severely affected.

Healthcare infrastructure was also destroyed, and there was no access to medical supplies, leading to people unable to get treatment. Not only were there food disruptions, but the water supply was cut off too. The Tigray Regional Water Bureau reported that only very few villages had access to water, leading to high risks of outbreaks of waterborne diseases. Blockades and Aid Access Despite efforts by the UN and international organizations to deliver food and medical supplies, the Ethiopian government had blocked off the region for months, preventing people from receiving help. Only about 900 000 people had received food aid, and most people were left to suffer. By late 2021, a shocking 4.5 million people did not have access to food. To make things worse, the government were accused of looting and preventing civilians from getting access to humanitarian aid.

Even after the ceasefire in 2022, humanitarian aid still could not be given as there were fuel shortages preventing transportation of goods. The World Food Programme had reported that fuel meant for humanitarian deliveries had been stolen by Tigray forces, stalling relief efforts.

Displacement and Refugee Crisis

By December 2020, more than a million people were forced to leave their homes in Ethiopia, and thousands more had to seek refuge in Sudan. These refugees had to face great dangers like abduction due to human traffickers.

Many Tigrayans were also reported to have been kidnapped, tortured, and transported to Libya, where they faced terrible conditions, causing many to die. Eritrean refugees also suffered in Tigray’s camps, where there was barely any food and supplies.

The UN reported that approximately 100 000 Eritrean refugees were facing shortages, and in February 2021, 20 000 refugees had gone missing.

Ongoing Suffering

The government’s refusal to allow humanitarian aid has led to the suffering of the people in Tigray, and as the conflict persists, millions of Ethiopians are still suffering from the lack of basic needs, leading to long term impacts on their health and livelihoods
